Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Characterization of a Conserved ATPase Required for Conjugation of Bacillus subtilis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Conjugation involves the transfer of DNA directly from a donor cell to a recipient cell. Since conjugative elements can deliver their own genetic material as well as other resident DNA, conjugation has played a profound role in bacterial evolution, allowing organisms to acquire new genes and adapt to new environmental niches. During conjugation, DNA is transferred from cell to cell through a specialized DNA translocation channel that is encoded by the conjugative element. This project will characterize the conserved ATPase ConE, a critical energetics component of the DNA translocation channel of the conjugative element ICEBs1 of Bacillus subtilis. This project is designed to reveal which conjugation proteins interact with and recruit ConE to the cell membrane. Furthermore, the sequences of ConE required for conjugation, ATP hydrolysis, and localization to the membrane will be explored. These studies should lead to the discovery of other critical components of the ICEBs1 conjugation machinery and a better understanding of the fundamental principles that govern horizontal gene transfer in bacteria.

Broader Impacts. Major impacts of this project are to enhance undergraduate student training while broadening our understanding of horizontal gene transfer. The research will be designed, conducted, and analyzed by undergraduate students with guidance from the PI. The PI will continue to integrate inquiry-based research into her undergraduate biochemistry laboratory course and high school outreach activities. Furthermore, this project will permit the purchase of a research-grade fluorescence microscope which will allow students to follow a wider range of research interests and learn sophisticated microscopy techniques. The percentage of students entering top-tier graduate programs and careers in the biosciences is expected to increase, as many more students will have the opportunity to gain useful research skills, present their work, and experience the excitement of scientific discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit
Conjugation is the transfer of DNA from a donor cell into a recipient cell through a specialized DNA translocation channel known as a Type IV secretion system (T4SS). Found in virtually all types of bacteria, conjugative DNA elements encode and move genes required for transfer. Conjugation also disseminates genes involved in metabolism and disease, thus playing a profound role in bacterial evolution and the acquisition of new traits. While there is a rich body of mechanistic and structural information on the T4SSs of Gram-negative bacteria, much less is known about those of Gram-positive bacteria. 

Our research has focused on characterizing the DNA translocation channel of ICEBs1, a conjugative element in the Gram-positive model bacterium Bacillus subtilis. Prior to this research, three known protein components of the ICEBs1 T4SS were the putative coupling protein ConQ, cell wall hydrolase CwlT and ATPase ConE. For this grant, one major goal was to biochemically characterize ConE. We identified five conserved residues near or in ConE’s active site that are critical for conjugation. We hypothesize that the five residues are involved in ATP sensing, binding, and/or hydrolysis. Furthermore, we found that purified ConE hydrolyzes ATP and forms higher-order oligomers. Future studies will test our model that ConE forms a doughnut-shaped hexamer that hydrolyzes ATP to energize DNA transfer and/or T4SS assembly.

A second major goal of this grant was to identify additional protein components of the ICEBs1 T4SS. We found that the putative membrane proteins ConB, ConC, ConD, and ConG are conserved, required for conjugation, and required for ICEBs1-mediated plasmid mobilization. Our results led us to propose a model in which the ICEBs1 conjugation machinery is composed of these four proteins, along with the previously identified ConE, CwlT, and ConQ. 

A third major goal was to determine how ConE localizes to the membrane. Prior work had indicated that ConE is a peripheral membrane protein that is unable to localize properly in the absence of ICEBs1. We found that ConB interacts with ConE and is required to recruit and/or maintain ConE at the membrane. Future experiments are aimed at characterizing both ConB and this interaction further. 

Broader Impacts
Major impacts of this grant were to enhance undergraduate training while broadening our understanding of the molecular mechanisms behind horizontal gene transfer. The research funded by this NSF grant was conducted by fourteen undergraduate students, allowing them to obtain invaluable experience. Of those fourteen students, six are underrepresented minorities, seven are first-generation college students, ten are female, and eight in the Honors and/or McNairs Scholars programs. Inquiry-based research related to this grant was also integrated into the undergraduate Advanced Biochemistry Research laboratory course taught by the PI each spring, exposing an additional ten students per year to the challenges and joy of authentic discovery. Furthermore, this grant allowed the purchase of a research-grade fluorescence microscope that allowed students to explore a wider range of research interests and learn sophisticated microscopy techniques. Altogether, this grant contributed to the development of a highly qualified and diverse STEM workforce.

This NSF-sponsored research resulted in several tangible outcomes, including two peer-reviewed journal articles, with a total of six undergraduate co-authors.
